awd_titl_txt: Engineering Synthetic Symbiosis Between Plant and Bacteria to Deliver Nitrogen to Crops
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: John W. Peters (Washington State University)

CoPIs: Jean-Michel Ane (University of Wisconsin - Madison), Maren Friesen (Washington State University), Michael Udvardi (The Samuel Roberts Nobel Foundation), Christopher A. Voigt (Massachusetts Institute of Technology)
 
Key Collaborators: Giles E. Oldroyd (John Innes Centre, UK) and Phillip S. Poole (John Innes Centre, Oxford University, UK)

Nitrogen is an essential element of biological molecules and life on earth.  Lack of usable nitrogen limits growth of microbes, plants, and animals. Scarcity of nitrogen in agricultural soils limits plant production of food, feed, fiber and fuel.  Nature solved the nitrogen limitation problem via evolution of biological nitrogen fixation in a type of bacteria, diazotrophs, that are able to reduce atmospheric N2 to NH3, which is readily assimilated into biological molecules.  Biological nitrogen fixation is promoted by a complex metal containing enzyme called nitrogenase, whose oxygen-sensitivity may explain its restricted distribution amongst bacteria.  Some plants, including most legumes and a few non-legumes form intimate, nitrogen-fixing symbioses with diazotrophs that provide the plants with ammonia.  As a consequence, legumes have been an integral part of sustainable agricultural systems for thousands of years.  Unfortunately, many important food species, including the grasses maize/corn, rice, and wheat cannot establish effective nitrogen-fixing symbioses with diazotrophs, making them dependent on nitrogenous fertilizers for high yield. Large-scale use of industrially-produced nitrogen-fertilizer has doubled the influx of nitrogen into the terrestrial biogeochemical nitrogen-cycle, with serious negative consequences for human health and the natural environment.   Therefore, the long-term sustainability of massive nitrogen-fertilizer inputs in agriculture has come into question. 

This project brings together an interdisciplinary team of investigators from the US and UK to solve the dual nitrogen problems of nitrogen-fertilizer over-use in developed countries and soil nitrogen-paucity in developing countries by developing effective endophytic (bacteria inside the root) and associative (bacteria attached outside the root) nitrogen-fixing symbioses in a model and a crop plant species.  The overarching goal of the project is to develop effective N2-fixing symbioses between the model C4-grass, Setaria viridis, as well as the related crop species, Zea mays, with the endophytic bacterium, Rhizobium sp. IRBG74, as well as the associative bacterium, Pseudomonas fluorescenes Pf5.  Successful deployment of biological nitrogen fixation in model or crop grass species will pave the way for a second Green Revolution to increase crop yields for resource-poor farmers and decrease the use and environmental-impact of industrial nitrogen-fertilizers by wealthier farmers. 

This project will establish a powerful new model system for the study of plant-microbe interactions and demonstrate the power of synthetic biology in engineering new associative relationships and interdependencies that have the potential to be universal for all crop plants.  It will test this potential in the important crop, maize.  The integrated US-UK research partnership will provide a unique training opportunity for students and post-doctoral associates with active exchange of personnel between academic laboratories and research foundations in both countries.  Data and materials generated in the study including plasmid constructs and genetically modified bacterial and plant species will be made available via websites maintained in the US and the UK.  To broaden the impact of the work, traditional and non-traditional outreach strategies will be used to help K-12 teachers, students, and the public understand the fundamentals and benefits of interdisciplinary research and the implications of synthetic biology for the next generation of biotechnological solutions in agriculture.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to develop effective synthetic N2-fixing symbioses between the crop grass species and the bacteria. Previous work by members of our team and others has revealed specific relationships between bacteria and plants that promote the growth of crop plants under nutrient-limiting conditions. The mechanisms by which bacteria colonize plants are poorly understood but, in some cases, involve the use of signals in the form of diffusible lipo-chitooligosaccharide (LCO) molecules and activation of the mycorrhizal signaling pathway. These signals and the like can be exploited in developing more intimate associations between cereals and rhizobia and the engineering of efficient nitrogen-fixing associations in cereals. The “Synthetic Symbioses” project funded through the “Ideas Lab” mechanism focuses on providing the fundamental basis for engineering microorganisms that are already robust colonizers for crop plants to possess lock-and-key interdependencies that involve the production of specialized carbon compounds in plants for use by their bacterial partner. In parallel, bacteria are engineered to produce ammonium from molecular nitrogen, via nitrogen-fixation, for use by the plant.

The main goal of this project was to conduct basic science to advance our understanding of the specific gene determinants of biological nitrogen fixation, plant and bacteria signaling to develop a blueprint to affect the transfer of these processes via synthetic biology approaches to bacteria chassis already known to be robust colonizers of crop plants. The project involved seven principal investigator-led research groups, five in the United States (US) supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF), and two in the United Kingdom (UK) supported by cofounding provided by Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council (BBSRC). A culmination of the work has provided the fundamental basis for developing a genetic system that responds to environmental signals, a plant carbon metabolite, and nutritional needs and, in turn, produces ammonia to promote crop growth under nitrogen limiting conditions. 

The work resulted in at least fourteen published scholarly works and at least two patents, including publications in high-impact journals (Nature Microbiology, Nature Communications, Trends in Microbiology) with an overall average impact factor of publication of ~7. The scholarly works included two review articles published in 2015 and 2016 that have been cited more than 100 times and several primary research articles cited more than 50 times. Most of the works were authored by more than one of the team’s principal investigators, and several involved collaborations between US and UK research groups. Amongst the more seminal of the findings included successful engineering of transkingdom signaling in plants to control gene expression in bacteria published in Nature Communications, engineering expression refactored nitrogen fixation and signaling gene products on a variety of target bacterial chassis published in Nature Microbiology, and the generation of ammonia excreting bacterial strains that promote plant growth under nitrogen limiting conditions which have been submitted for publication recently. In sum, the intellectual merit reflected in the published or soon to be published works providing the basis for engineering symbiosis to promote the growth of crops plants and lays the groundwork for seminal advances in biotechnology. The broader impacts are reflected in the training of ten post-doctoral researchers, nine of which have successfully gone to faculty positions and two of which are at primarily minority-serving institutions. In addition, the content of nitrogen fixation and its importance in agriculture have been incorporated into a “Science Horizons” program that facilitates the development of curriculum content for high school and tribal college teachers and opportunities for Native American high school students as part of the Montana Apprenticeship Program (MAP). The programing utilized for MAP involved the isolation of nitrogen-fixing microorganisms from soil was published for broader consumption in an article in the journal American Biology Teacher citing NSF support.
